A sign that is suspended from the underside of a principal building's overhang or canopy that is
intended for view by pedestrians or patrons already on a site. The sign may be parallel or
a. Definition
perpendicular to the building wall. A sign that is not suspended from a canopy or overhang of a
building is not a suspended sign. A sign mounted on a building wall parallel to the wall is a "wall"
sign. A sign mounted on a building wall perpendicular to the building wall is a "projecting" sign.
Signs visible through a window are "window" signs.
b. Zoning
Districts Where
Permitted
C. Dimensional Standards
NOTES:
[1] Any suspended sign that projects into a right-of-way or that projects over a sidewalk, walkway, or vehicular
accessway shall maintain a minimum clearance of at least 9 feet above the grade or the walkway.
[2] A suspended sign shall maintain a minimum of two feet of horizontal distance from the back of the curb.
d. Additional Standards
i. Suspended signs shall not project beyond the canopy or overhang they are mounted to.
ii. Suspended signs shall be flush mounted or drop mounted with metal pipe, chain, wire, or other comparable material
and permanently affixed to the overhang or canopy where mounted.
iii. Suspended signs shall not be mounted to an accessory structure.
iv. Signage may be subject to additional standards identified in Section 3.20.D, Gateway Corridor Overlay (GCO) District.
V. A suspended sign may only be established on a lot with a principal structure.

frame is permitted provided the sign does not show visible disrepair (fading, torn corners, etc.).

A sign made of a flexible fabric or plastic material that is affixed to a building or other vertical
a. Definition
projection, except utility poles, but is not an awning sign or a flag. Feather flags and bow signs
are not banners and are prohibited by this Ordinance.
b. Zoning
Districts Where
Permitted
NOTES:
[1] Maximum of 3 banners per multi-tenant development at any one time.
[2] When located on a fence, wall, or as a freestanding banner, a maximum height of 12 feet to the highest point. When
located on a building wall, the banner shall not be mounted above the first floor.
[3] Banners in a multiple-lot development subject to a single site plan or master plan shall be at least 10 feet from the outside
perimeter boundary of the development.
[4] Placement of a banner shall require prior issuance of a temporary use permit in accordance with Section 2.4.V, Temporary
Use Permit.
d. Additional Standards
i. Banners shall be adequately secured through the use of grommets, d-rings, brackets, or similar fastening devices.
ii. Banners over 9 square feet in size shall incorporate wind slits.
iii. Banners shall not be placed within required sight distance triangles or in locations that obstruct the safe movement of
vehicles and pedestrians.
iv. Signage may be subject to additional standards identified in Section 3.20.D, Gateway Corridor Overlay (GCO) District.
V. Except for open air uses of land, a banner may only be established on a lot with a principal structure.

by this Ordinance.

Any sign, other than a projecting sign, that is mounted to or painted on an exterior building wall.
Wall signs have only one sign face and are configured to be parallel to the building wall upon
a. Wall Sign
which they are located. Signs mounted perpendicular to a wall are "projecting" signs. Signs
Definition
mounted from the ceiling of a building's canopy or overhang are "suspended" signs. Signs made
of fabric or other material that moves are "banners" or "flags." Signs visible through a window
are "window" signs.

Maximum Number of Signs and Maximum Sign Face Area
NOTES:

building, regardless of the number of individual wall signs on the façade. It is also the total amount of allowable wall
sign face area per individual tenant wall frontage in a multi-tenant building (see Section 8.3.M, Signage Measurement,
for determination of individual tenant wall frontage).
[3] The maximum allowable wall sign face area may increase by 0.5 sf per linear foot of façade for each additional
building story above the third floor where the sign is placed.
[4] Does not include large format retail establishments.
[5] End units in a multi-tenant building may have a wall sign on a primary, secondary, and tertiary building façade.
[6] Wall signs not permitted on secondary or tertiary building facades.
[7] Wall signs that project into a right-of-way shall maintain a minimum vertical clearance of at least 9 feet above grade.
[8] Wall signs shall not project into a right-of-way by more than six inches.
d. Additional Standards for Wall Signs
i. No wall sign shall be located in a manner that covers or blocks ingress or egress from a door, window, or fire escape.
ii. Any electrical wiring shall be located within the sign or the wall it is affixed to.
iii. Wall signs on secondary or tertiary building walls abutting a residential use shall not be illuminated.
iv. Wall signs that are illuminated shall comply with the applicable limitations on glare in Section 5.7, Exterior Lighting.
V. Signage may be subject to additional standards identified in Section 3.20.D, Gateway Corridor Overlay (GCO) District.
vi. A wall sign face area may consist of durable, UV resistant, professionally printed fabric stretched taught over an
interior frame is permitted provided the sign does not show visible disrepair (fading, torn corners, etc.).
vii. A wall sign may only be established on a lot with a principal structure.

NOTES:
[1] See Section 8.3.N, Building Façade Type, for building façade type determination.
[2] This is the total amount of allowable wall sign face area per façade of a single-tenant or a large format retail

sign face area per individual tenant wall frontage in a multi-tenant building (see Section 8.3.M, Signage Measurement,
for determination of individual tenant wall frontage).
[3] The maximum allowable wall sign face area may increase by 0.5 sf per linear foot of façade for each additional
building story above the third floor where the sign is placed.
[4] Does not include large format retail establishments.
[5] End units in a multi-tenant building may have a wall sign on a primary, secondary, and tertiary building façade.
[6] Wall signs not permitted on secondary or tertiary building facades.
[7] Wall signs that project into a right-of-way shall maintain a minimum vertical clearance of at least 9 feet above grade.
[8] Wall signs shall not project into a right-of-way by more than six inches.
d. Additional Standards for Wall Signs
i. No wall sign shall be located in a manner that covers or blocks ingress or egress from a door, window, or fire escape.
ii. Any electrical wiring shall be located within the sign or the wall it is affixed to.
iii. Wall signs on secondary or tertiary building walls abutting a residential use shall not be illuminated.
iv. Wall signs that are illuminated shall comply with the applicable limitations on glare in Section 5.7, Exterior Lighting.
V. Signage may be subject to additional standards identified in Section 3.20.D, Gateway Corridor Overlay (GCO) District.
vi. A wall sign face area may consist of durable, UV resistant, professionally printed fabric stretched taught over an
interior frame is permitted provided the sign does not show visible disrepair (fading, torn corners, etc.).
vii. A wall sign may only be established on a lot with a principal structure.
